title: Macquarie's G&W rail purchase 'conflicted,' US investor says
text:
Aurizon's efforts to block the sale of US rail group Genesee & Wyoming's Australian business to Macquarie Infrastructure have been welcomed by a shareholder of the American company, who says the local operations are being offloaded at a "fire sale" price.

Boutique investor and research group Dalrymple Finance, which is run by Victoria and Keith Dalrymple, has asked US regulators to block the $US8.4 billion sale of G &W to Brookfield Infrastructure and Singapore's GIC fund at the same time as Aurizon is challenging the sale of G&W Australia to Macquarie in the courts.

The Dalrymples, who founded the Responsible Governance and Investment Council, told G &W's board ahead of an October 3 shareholder vote on the deal that the motivations of Brookfield and Macquarie appeared "conflicted".

Joint venture partners who did not secure financing ... bought the business on short notice at a fire sale price. — Dalrymple Finance

They pointed out the sale of the Australian business was arranged by Brookfield after Macquarie was hired to advise on a debt refinancing of the rail assets that never happened.

"It remains unclear why G &W management did not conduct negotiations with its joint venture partners who did not secure financing but bought the business on short notice at a fire sale price through a third party," Ms Dalrymple said in a letter to G &W directors obtained by The Australian Financial Review.
description: More questions are being asked about the sale of Genesee & Wyoming's Australian rail business to Macquarie Infrastructure.
